Knowledge Point: interrogatively. It may, beside its primary static reading, as in (\ref{ex:7-1}), also imply goal, as in
Content 1: \gll áaḍ-a \textbf{índa} bhíl-a áaḍ-a ba naaṛéy-a the ɡíia | \gls half-MPL here become.PFV"=MPL half-MPL TOP Narey-OBL to go.PFV.PL | \glt `Some remained here, while others went to Narey.'
\gll \textbf{táa} yhaí ba ɡóo hín-u bhraapútr thaníit-u | \gls there come.CV TOP where be.PRS"=MSG nephew say.PFV"=MSG | \glt `When he came there, he said, ``Where is he, nephew?'''

Knowledge Point: expressing a~movement away from a~location, as in example (\ref{ex:7-3}), or an~origin in a~certain
Content 1: \gll \textbf{eetáai} wheel-í ɡhróom-a phedóol-u | \gls from.there take.down-CV village-OBL bring.PFV"=MSG | \glt `Getting it [the corpse] down from there, we brought it to the village.'

Knowledge Point: in (\ref{ex:7-4}), the members of the oblique series have to be used instead of those of the
Content 1: \gll ṣiṣ ba \textbf{aníi=wee} bi buṭ-í \textbf{aníi=wee} bi buṭ-í | \gls head TOP 3SG.PROX.OBL=in also plait-CV 3SG.PROX.OBL=in also plait-CV | \glt `As for his hair, it was braided into many braids.'

Knowledge Point: \spitzmarke{huṇḍ `up'.} This essentially nominal adverb is used for a~location situated in a~more or less vertical upward direction (not necessarily visible) from the point of reference. Used alone it can refer to a~location `up (there)', as in (\ref{ex:7-5}), as well as a~movement to such a~location.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{huṇḍ} ta c̣hiítr=ee \textbf{bhun} ba ɡhaawaáz de | \gls above CNTR field=CNJ below TOP stream.bed be.PST | \glt `The field was up above and the sand and stream were down below.'

Knowledge Point: From huṇḍ, a~number of other semantically related adverbs or adverbial phrases can be derived: huṇḍ the/húṇṭe `up (to)', as in (\ref{ex:7-6}); huṇḍíi/huṇḍíi thíi `from above'; huṇḍɡiraá (A), example (\ref{ex:7-7}); or huṇṭeɡiráak/huṇṭráak (B) `upward, uphill', huṇḍaṛáa ({\textless} huṇḍ + eeṛáa) `up there'.
Content 1: \gll sum \textbf{huṇḍ} \textbf{the} ṣuɡal-í ba čo ba thaníit-u | \gls soil up to throw-CV TOP go go.IMP.SG say.PFV"=MSG | \glt `He threw soil up [in the air] and said, ``Go on!'''
Content 2: \gll \textbf{huṇḍɡiraá} dac̣h-íin ta iṇc̣ muṭ-íi phúṭi ǰhulí bheš-í áaṇc̣-a kha-áan-u | \gls upward look-3PL SUB bear tree-GEN top on sit-CV raspberry-PL eat-PRS"=MSG | \glt `They were looking up and saw the bear sitting in the top of the tree eating raspberries.'

Knowledge Point: \spitzmarke{bhun `down'.} This essentially nominal adverb is used for a~location situated downward or below the point of reference. Used alone it can refer to a~location, `down (there)' as in (\ref{ex:7-5}), as well as a~movement to such a~location, as in (\ref{ex:7-8}). The following adverbs or adverbial phrases are examples of derivations from bhun: bhún the/bhuná `down (to)', bhuníi thíi `from below', bhunɡiraá (A) or bhunteɡiráak/bhuntráak (B) `downward', bhunimaá `(on the way) downhill', exemplified in (\ref{ex:7-9}), bhunaṛáa (and other deictic forms based on it) `down there'.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{huṇḍ} ta c̣hiítr=ee \textbf{bhun} ba ɡhaawaáz de | \gls above CNTR field=CNJ below TOP stream.bed be.PST | \glt `The field was up above and the sand and stream were down below.'
Content 2: \gll so méeš hatí maǰí-e uṭik-í \textbf{bhun} whaí ba uḍheew-í wháat-u | \gls DEM.MSG.NOM man 3SG.REM.OBL in-GEN jump-CV down come.down.CV TOP flee-CV come.down.PFV"=MSG | \glt `Meanwhile, the man jumped down [from the tree] and fled down [to the village].'
Content 3: \gll tuúš \textbf{bhunimaá} wh-íi ta karáaṛu ukh-áand-u | \gls some downhill come.down-3SG SUB leopard come.up-PRS"=MSG | \glt `Getting some ways downhill, [he meets] the leopard coming up.'

Knowledge Point: \spitzmarke{aǰá (B aǰé) `up (there)'.} This essentially deictic adverb is used for a~location situated upstream or in a~slightly upward location from the point of reference (compare with huṇḍ which implies a~place more or less straight above the point of reference). Used alone it can refer to a~location, `up/over (there), upstream', as well as a~movement to such a~location, as in (\ref{ex:7-10}). Although not quite as productive as huṇḍ and bhun, this adverb is similarly used as a~building block for other adverbs and adverbial expressions, such as aǰimaá `upward', aǰaṛáa `up/over there', aǰí/aǰí thíi (B) `from upstreams/up"=country'.
Content 1: \gll yáab ɡhaš-í \textbf{aǰá} ɡúum ta | \gls canal take-CV up go.PFV.MSG SUB | \glt `I went up along the [irrigation] canal.'

Knowledge Point: \spitzmarke{túuri `down (there)'.} This adverb, otherwise mostly used as a~postposition (see \sectref{subsec:7-2-2}), is only occasionally used without a~noun or pronoun as an~argument. It seems to be contrasting with the aforementioned adverb in describing a~location or movement downstream from the point of reference, such as in (\ref{ex:7-11}). It may also be followed by the postposition wée (see \sectref{subsec:7-2-2}).
Content 1: \gll dúe xálaka ba \textbf{túuri} dhrúuk-a ǰe ɡéa | \gls other people TOP down gorge-OBL down.to go.PFV.PL | \glt `The other people went down into the valley.'

Knowledge Point: \spitzmarke{rhalá `up (above, on top)'.} This adverbial expression, related to the adjective raál (primarily occurring as as a~host element in conjunct verbs with meanings such as `raise, lift up'), is used for describing the position on top of a~structure or object, as in example (\ref{ex:7-12}). In some sentences its function may rather be analysed as that of a~manner adverb or a~postposition.
Content 1: \gll dúi hiimaál whaí ṭópa traác̣ de asaám \textbf{rhalá} ɡaḍíl-a | \gls other glacier come.down.CV down HOST give.CV 1PL.ACC up take.out.PFV"=MPL | \glt `Another avalanche struck came and brought us out [from under the snow].'

Knowledge Point: \spitzmarke{awaaɡír `up high, at a~high elevation'.} This adverbial expression (possibly also adjectival) seems to be exclusively used for referring to a~high elevation in the mountains, as in (\ref{ex:7-12b}).
Content 1: \gll paṇáar-u táapaṛ thaní \textbf{awaaɡír} qaribán dúu thiáaḍ-a míil-a táapaṛ hín-u | \gls white-MSG hill QUOT high.up about two and.half-MPL mile-PL hill be.PRS"=MSG | \glt `There is a hill called the White Hill about two and a half kilometers up.'

Knowledge Point: reference, as in (\ref{ex:7-13}), often in contrast with oóra `on this side, over here'
Content 1: \gll ɡhoortsí bi so áa kučúru bi uḍheew-í [oóra] šan-á so šay bi tanaám sanɡí yhaí šan-á, ma ba \textbf{phará} khilaí dharíit-u | \gls Ghortsi also DEF.MSG.NOM one dog also flee.CV over.here roof-OBL DEM.MSG.NOM thing also 3PL.ACC with come.CV roof-OBL 1SG.NOM TOP yonder alone remain.PFV"=MSG | \glt `Both Ghortsi [the name of a dog] and the other dog fled from that thing and went back to the roof over here. The thing followed them onto the roof, but I stayed by myself, away from there.'

Knowledge Point: \spitzmarke{oóra `on this side, over here'.} As already mentioned and exemplified in (\ref{ex:7-13}), this deictic adverb is used in contrast with phará, implying a~location close to the point of reference as opposed to a~location further away. I am not aware of any derivations from this adverb.
Content 1: \gll ɡhoortsí bi so áa kučúru bi uḍheew-í [oóra] šan-á so šay bi tanaám sanɡí yhaí šan-á, ma ba \textbf{phará} khilaí dharíit-u | \gls Ghortsi also DEF.MSG.NOM one dog also flee.CV over.here roof-OBL DEM.MSG.NOM thing also 3PL.ACC with come.CV roof-OBL 1SG.NOM TOP yonder alone remain.PFV"=MSG | \glt `Both Ghortsi [the name of a dog] and the other dog fled from that thing and went back to the roof over here. The thing followed them onto the roof, but I stayed by myself, away from there.'

Knowledge Point: \spitzmarke{patú `behind, in back'.} This basic form is, according to my material, only used as a~postpostion (in A) or conjunction (in B), see \sectref{subsec:7-2-2}; however, a~couple of (partly spatial, partly temporal) adverbial expressions are clearly derived from it: patuɡiraá (exemplified in (\ref{ex:7-14}))/patuɡiróo/paturaá (A)/patuɡiráak (B) `back', \textit{padúši ({\textless} patú + dúši)} `behind', as in (\ref{ex:7-15}), the latter almost exclusively used in a~temporal sense in B (compare with \sectref{subsec:7-1-3}).
Content 1: \gll se páand \textbf{patuɡiraá} na lháay-a de | \gls 3FSG.NOM path back NEG find-3SG PST | \glt `It did not find its way back.'
Content 2: \gll bakáara ta muṣṭú bhe whéet-i=ee be ba \textbf{padúši} wh-áand-a | \gls flock CNTR in.front become.CV come.down.PFV-F=CNJ 1PL.NOM TOP behind come.down-PRS"=MPL | \glt `The flock got down before us, and then we came down behind.'

Knowledge Point: \spitzmarke{muṣṭú (A only) `in front, ahead, forward'.} As with the aforementioned adverbial group, muṣṭú has in addition to its basic spatial meaning, as in (\ref{ex:7-16}), acquired some largely temporal aspects (see \sectref{subsec:7-1-3}). A nearly synonymous muṣṭuɡiraá is also derived from it.
Content 1: \gll tuúš \textbf{muṣṭú} bíi ta áak luumái ḍhoó dít-i hín-i | \gls some in.front go.3SG SUB IDEF fox sight give.PFV-F be.PRS-F | \glt `Going some distance forward, he saw a~fox.'

Knowledge Point: \spitzmarke{nhiáaṛa (B niháaṛa) `near, nearby'.} This adverb is often used in a~so"=called compound postposition (\sectref{subsec:7-2-3}) but may also be used alone, see (\ref{ex:7-17}), as a~spatial adverb.
Content 1: \gll tasíi ba páanǰ ṣo bhraawú \textbf{nhiáaṛa} hóons"=an de | \gls 3SG.GEN TOP five six brother.PL near stay-3PL PST | \glt `Five or six of her brothers were living nearby.'

Knowledge Point: \spitzmarke{dhúura `far away'.} Like the aforementioned adverb, it is often used in a~compound postposition (\sectref{subsec:7-2-3}), but may also be used independently (\ref{ex:7-17b}).
Content 1: \gll \textbf{dhúura} áa ɣar-í učát ɣar-í eeṛáa piír hín-u | \gls far.away IDEF peak-OBL high peak-OBL there.REM pir be.PRS"=MSG | \glt `Far away, on the top of a high mountain, there is a pir [a holy person].'

Knowledge Point: dynamically, as in example (\ref{ex:7-18}), as a~spatial adverb.
Content 1: \gll ma \textbf{šíiṭi} be tes sanɡí madád th-áam | \gls 1SG.NOM inside go.CV 3SG.ACC with help do-1SG | \glt `I will go inside and help him.'

Knowledge Point: \spitzmarke{aḍaphaár `halfway, midway'.} Composed of \textit{*aḍa {\textgreater} áaḍa} `half' and *phaar (see above) `yonder', it is used in this essentially nominal form for the movement up to a~point somewhere right between the point of origin and an~expected goal, but it may occur in an~oblique form aḍaphará with no obvious difference in meaning, a~form to which the postposition tií (\sectref{subsec:7-2-2}) can be added, rendering the approximate meaning `as far as halfway'. It can also occur in the genitive aḍapharíi `from the middle', as seen in example (\ref{ex:7-19}).
Content 1: \gll \textbf{aḍapharíi} huṇḍ the ta ǰaláṣ bhun the ba lhíst-u | \gls from.middle up to CNTR hairy down to TOP bald-MSG | \glt `It was half hairless and half covered in hair. The top half was hairy and the bottom half was hairless.'

Knowledge Point: used for referring to the present moment, as illustrated in (\ref{ex:7-20}), as well as to
Content 1: \gll \textbf{típa} ba ma tasíi paalaweeṇíi qiseé tháan-u | \gls now TOP 1SG.NOM 3SG.GEN strongmanship.GEN story.PL do.PRS"=MSG | \glt `Now I am telling the stories about his strongmanship.'

Knowledge Point: \spitzmarke{muṣṭú (A)/muxáak (B) `before, in the past, once'.} The A adverb has spatial functions (see \sectref{subsec:7-1-2}) along with its temporal ones. Both the A and the B adverb may take additional modifiers, such as degree adverbs (bíiḍu muṣṭú `long before, a~long time ago') or calendrical expressions (dúu yúuna muxáak `two months ago'). The meaning `since then, for a~long time' can be expressed by muṣṭúi niiɡiraá. A sentence with the B adverb muxáak is given in (\ref{ex:7-21}).
Content 1: \gll \textbf{muxáak} be iskuul-í the b-íia de | \gls before 1PL.NOM school-OBL to go-1PL PST | \glt `Once, we were going to school...'

Knowledge Point: \spitzmarke{eetheél/(eesé) waxtíi `at that time, in those days, then'.} Usually, for reference to a~specific time (usually in the past), as in (\ref{ex:7-22}), the genitive of the noun waxt (or waqt) `time' is used with a~preceding demonstrative (if referred to contextually) or another identifying modifier (kufurdóore waxtíe `in the pagan era' B), but also the synchronically non"=derived adverb eetheél, possibly more widely used in the past, is still in use, as can be seen in example (\ref{ex:7-23}). The latter can refer to a~point of time in the past as well as in the future (e.g., in eetheél tií `before that time, up to that time'). The genitive of the English loan ṭeém `time' is used in a~way quite similar to waxtíi, taking various modifiers, such as basandíi ṭeemíi `at spring time'.
Content 1: \gll neečíir ba eesé \textbf{waxt-íi} bíiḍ-i | \gls hunting TOP REM time-GEN much-F | \glt `Hunting was a common custom at that time.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{eetheél} maidaaní ǰanɡ de | \gls that.time of.field war be.PST | \glt `In those days there used to be fighting in the fields.'

Knowledge Point: \spitzmarke{aakatí waxtí (maǰí)/waxt bhe/padúši (B) `later, after some time'.} A number of expressions, some of them containing forms of the noun waxt, are used when referring to a~later point in time, in (\ref{ex:7-24}) with the converb of bhe- `become' (compare manner adverbs formed with converbs, \sectref{subsec:7-1-4}). Only in the B variety is padúši used in a~clearly temporal sense (see \sectref{subsec:7-1-2}).
Content 1: \gll khéli \textbf{waxt} \textbf{bhe} dac̣h-íi ta | \gls quite.some time become.CV look-3SG SUB | \glt `Some time later he was looking.'

Knowledge Point: Adjectival derivations with -úk- are also used in expressing similar temporal"=deictic propositions, e.g., tipúku `of now, ``nowish''', muṣṭúku `of the past, of old, ``oldish''', as seen in (\ref{ex:7-25}), eetheelúku `of that time' (see \tabref{tab:7-2} on p.~\pageref{tab:7-2}).
Content 1: \gll \textbf{muṣṭúk-a} xálak-a dhii-á díi na khooǰ-óon de | \gls of.past-MPL people-PL daughter-OBL from NEG ask-3PL PST | \glt `People in the old days were not asking their daughter [who she wanted to marry].'

Knowledge Point: The most common calendrical adverbs (\tabref{tab:7-cal}) used deictically are synchronically non"=derived. In (\ref{ex:7-26}), the use of dhoóṛ `yesterday' is illustrated.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{dhoóṛ} índa kir dít-u de típa bi kir hín-u | \gls yesterday here snow give.PFV"=MSG PST now also snow be.PRS"=MSG | \glt `It was snowing here yesterday, and even now there is snow.'

Knowledge Point: Although heeṇṣúka `this year' diachronically may be an~adjectivally derived form (with -úk-), it is used like the other non"=derived deictic adverbs, as in (\ref{ex:7-27}), without modifying a~noun head.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{heeṇṣúka} ma čiiríit-u | \gls this.year 1SG.NOM be.delayed.PFV"=MSG | \glt `This year I'm delayed.'

Knowledge Point: Belonging semantically to this group is also rhootašíia (with the alternative forms rhoošíia and rhoošée) `tomorrow', used as in (\ref{ex:7-28}), which, however, is the oblique case of the noun rhootašíi `morning'.
Content 1: \gll ma nis aáǰ kh-úum ta \textbf{rhootašíi-a} ba kanáa bh-úum | \gls 1SG.NOM 3SG.ACC today eat-1SG SUB morning-OBL TOP like.what become-1SG | \glt `If I eat this today, what will then become of me tomorrow.'

Knowledge Point: The identity of most calendrical cyclic expressions (\tabref{tab:7-2}), on the other hand, is clearly nominal, although the oblique case forms can be said to have been lexicalised as adverbs. In (\ref{ex:7-29}), the use of heewandá, róota and deesá can be seen.
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: While the above oblique forms of the calendrical nouns express a ``temporal location'', a~couple of these and a~number of other temporal nouns (such as kaál `year', yúun `month', haftá `week') may be used in various forms and derivations to express temporal quantities or frequences. The examples (\ref{ex:7-30})--(\ref{ex:7-39}) all constitute adverbial phrases in Palula.
Content 1: \gll har deés | \gls every day | \glt `every day'
Content 2: \gll dúi kaal-á the | \gls other year-OBL to | \glt `another year, next year'

Knowledge Point: time"=of"=day adverbs. Two exceptions are rhoošnaám `morning' (in (\ref{ex:7-40})) and
Content 1: \gll \textbf{dhrumanaám} ba pašambeé ta c̣hóoṇ-ii bháaru ɡhin-í ma ba ɡúči | \gls afternoon TOP Pashambi CNTR oak-GEN load take-CV 1SG.NOM TOP free | \glt `In the afternoon Pashambi carried fodder [to the goats] while I was free.'

Knowledge Point: non"=emphatic form andáa). For modifying an~intransitive predicate, as in (\ref{ex:7-42}),
Content 1: \gll \textbf{andáa=bhe} praš-í wée baṭ-á wh-áand-a | \gls like.that=become.CV slope-OBL in stone-PL come.down-PRS"=MPL | \glt `Just like that, stones came down the slope.'

Knowledge Point: bhe is used, for modifying a~transitive predicate, as in (\ref{ex:7-43}), the is
Content 1: \gll dharéndi mháalu dac̣h-áaṭ-u bhíl-u hín-u siɡréṭ dhrak-í ba \textbf{andáa=the} | \gls outside father look-AG"=MSG become.PFV"=MSG be.PRS"=MSG cigarette pull-CV TOP like.that=do.CV | \glt `While looking at his father outside, he was smoking the cigarette like that.'

Knowledge Point: Also ideophonic expressions, without any specific or standardised lexical source, such as those in (\ref{ex:7-44}), can be made manner adverbs this way. (The adverbs in the English translation in (\ref{ex:7-44}) are only approximate equivalents of the Converb cum reduplicated ideophone complexes.\footnote{A widespread covariation of so"=called periphrastic `do'-constructions and reduplicated stems has been noted by \citet{jaeger2006}.})
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Forming a~small class, non"=derived degree adverbs are mainly used as modifiers of other adverbs but also as quantifiers of nouns, especially non"=count nouns. The list in \tabref{tab:7-deg} is not meant to be exhaustive. See (\ref{ex:7-9}) for an~example with tuúš.
Content 1: \gll tuúš \textbf{bhunimaá} wh-íi ta karáaṛu ukh-áand-u | \gls some downhill come.down-3SG SUB leopard come.up-PRS"=MSG | \glt `Getting some ways downhill, [he meets] the leopard coming up.'

Knowledge Point: These deictic degree adverbs intensify adjectives, meaning `such, so', as in (\ref{ex:7-45}), and `what, how', as in (\ref{ex:7-46}). (Note that katí in particular also functions as a~direct quantifying modifier of a~noun head, meaning `how much, how many'.)
Content 1: \gll baṣ \textbf{hatí} teéz bhíl-u ooḍháal whéet-i | \gls rain such strong become.PFV"=MSG flood come.down.PFV-F | \glt `The rain became so strong that it flooded.'
Content 2: \gll nu ba \textbf{katí} utháal-u táapaṛ | \gls 3MSG.PROX.NOM TOP how.much high-MSG hill | \glt `What a~high hill!'

Knowledge Point: full reduplication, as seen in (\ref{ex:7-47}), or reduplication of the first syllable. In example
Content 1: \gll wháat-a andáa=bhe \textbf{bhraáš} \textbf{bhraáš} | \gls come.down.PFV"=MPL like.that=become.CV RED slowly | \glt `We came down like that, very slowly.'

Knowledge Point: (\ref{ex:7-48}) both full and first"=syllable reduplication are being used.
Content 1: \gll mhaamaǰaán ba \textbf{la-láp} \textbf{la-láp} khóo de | \gls Mahmad.Jan TOP RED-fast RED-fast eat.3SG PST | \glt `Mahmad Jan was eating very fast.'

Knowledge Point: Sentence adverbs (\tabref{tab:7-sadv}) modify entire utterances. They may for instance specify the speaker's attitude toward the event referred to, or emphasise its truth"=value, as in (\ref{ex:7-48b}).
Content 1: \gll so ba \textbf{rištaá} xučháii so máamu | \gls 3MSG.NOM TOP really Khush.Shah.GEN DEF.MSG.NOM uncle | \glt `He was indeed Khush Shah's uncle.'

Knowledge Point: \spitzmarke{the `to, for'.} This postposition takes an~oblique nominal argument, `house' in (\ref{ex:7-50}), or an~accusative pronominal argument, `them' and `us' in (\ref{ex:7-49}). There is a~wide range of meanings, all having the core semantics of marking the recipient of a~transaction or the goal of a~movement.
Content 1: \gll ma bhíiru ɡhin-í thíi \textbf{ɡhooṣṭ-á} \textbf{the} yhúum | \gls 1SG.NOM he.goat take-CV 2SG.GEN house-OBL to come.1SG | \glt `I'll take a~goat with me and come to your house.'
Content 2: \gll na ta \textbf{tanaám} \textbf{the} dít-i na ba \textbf{asaám} \textbf{the} dít-i | \gls NEG CNTR 3PL.ACC to give.PFV-F NEG TOP 1PL.ACC to give.PFV-F | \glt `Neither did they give them [the guns] to them, nor to us.'

Knowledge Point: Apart from marking the recipient in a~typical ``ditransitive'' clause, the can also identify a~beneficiary in a~transitive clause and the recipient of an~abstract entity, such as in the utterance in (\ref{ex:7-51}).
Content 1: \gll dhii-á \textbf{mac̣hook-á} \textbf{the} maníit-u... | \gls daughter-OBL Machoke-OBL to say.PFV"=MSG | \glt `The daughter told Machoke...'

Knowledge Point: If the marks a~goal expressed as a~spatial pro"=adverb (also functioning as an~inanimate/abstract demonstrative pronoun), the locative member of the set, táa `there', as in (\ref{ex:7-52}), is used. However, if the goal of a~movement carried out by a~person is another person, the postpositions khúna or kéeči (see below) have to be used instead.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{táa} \textbf{the} misrí bulaḍ-eeṇḍeéu | \gls there to mason call.for-OBLG | \glt `A mason is called to there [to see to that].'

Knowledge Point: \spitzmarke{díi `from, (out) of, than'.} This postposition takes an~oblique nominal argument, `the Damelis' in (\ref{ex:7-53}), or an~accusative pronominal argument. There is a~wide range of meanings, all referring to the source of a~transaction or the point of origin/reference.
Content 1: \gll ṛaním eeṛé riwaayát ... \textbf{ɡiḍúuč-am} \textbf{díi} ɡhíin-i hín-i | \gls 3PL.DIST.ERG DIST tradition ... Dameli-OBL.PL from take.PFV-F be.PRS-F | \glt `They have received [lit: taken] this tradition from the Damelis.'

Knowledge Point: A~place as the source or starting point for a~movement is almost always expressed with the genitive (along with the postposition thíi). In contrast, díi is primarily postposed to nouns denoting human sources, such as `my grandmother' and `my father' in (\ref{ex:7-54}). The transferred, or brought forth, entity, however, can be abstract, such as an~utterance, as well as concrete, for instance in expressing the animate source of reproduction, as in (\ref{ex:7-55}).
Content 1: \gll \textbf{míi} \textbf{déedi} \textbf{díi} míi ṣúunt-u \textbf{míi} \textbf{báaba} \textbf{díi} míi ṣúunt-u | \gls 1SG.GEN grandmother from 1SG.GEN hear.PFV"=MSG 1SG.GEN father.OBL from 1SG.GEN hear.PFV"=MSG | \glt `I heard it from my grandmother, and I heard it from my father.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{khar-á} \textbf{díi} khar ǰa-yáan-u | \gls donkey-OBL from donkey be.born\textsf{-}PRS"=MSG | \glt `A donkey is born by a~donkey.'

Knowledge Point: Some arguments with díi are part of the valence pattern of some complex predicates (\sectref{subsec:12-2-8}), and Verbal Nouns in complements of negative implicative predicates are also taken as arguments by díi (\sectref{subsec:13-5-2}). The possessor in one main (primarily alienable, as the `mason's hammer' in (\ref{ex:7-56})) possessional construction is also marked with díi.
Content 1: \gll misrí yhóol-u seentá \textbf{misrí} \textbf{díi} tsaṭák hóons-a | \gls mason come.PFV"=MSG when mason from hammer stay-3SG | \glt `When the mason comes he will have a~hammer [lit: When the mason has come, from the mason a~hammer will be present].'

Knowledge Point: \spitzmarke{sanɡí `(along) with, at'.} This postposition takes an~oblique nominal argument or an~accusative pronominal argument. It typically expresses accompaniment, as in (\ref{ex:7-57}).
Content 1: \gll ḍaaku"=aan-óom yhaí \textbf{bakáara-m} \textbf{sanɡí} tas ɡhaš-í híṛ-u de | \gls robber-PL"=OBL come.CV flock-OBL with 3SG.ACC take-CV take.away.PFV"=MSG PST | \glt `The robbers came and abducted him along with his flock.'

Knowledge Point: Used with an~inanimate noun, such as the `tree' in (\ref{ex:7-58}), it can have a~further connotation of being attached to.
Content 1: \gll ma tu ráaǰ-a de ɡhaṇḍ-í ɡal-áan-u \textbf{aní} \textbf{muṭ-á} \textbf{sanɡí} | \gls 1SG.NOM 2SG.NOM rope give.CV tie-CV throw-PRS"=MSG PROX tree-OBL with | \glt `I will tie you with ropes to this tree.'

Knowledge Point: \spitzmarke{ǰhulí `on (top of), on to, over, about, due to'.} This postposition takes an~oblique nominal argument or (in most cases) an~accusative pronominal argument in its essentially spatial sense `on, onto' and an~oblique pronominal argument in more abstract senses such as `about, concerning'. It typically expresses a~position on the immediate surface of something, such as the `stone' in (\ref{ex:7-59}), or somebody. It is also used for the movement onto the surface or into the position on top of something or somebody.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{se} \textbf{baṭ-á} \textbf{ǰhulí} se kuṇaak-íi paaṇṭí bi heensíl-i de | \gls DEF stone-OBL on DEF child-GEN clothes also stay.PFV-F PST | \glt `On the stone were also the child's clothes.'

Knowledge Point: A pronoun referring to an~inanimate but still concrete entity can also (optionally it seems) occur in the oblique form with this postposition, the case otherwise used in pronominal reference to abstract entities (as in example (\ref{ex:7-60})). Note that the oblique pronoun (which is the same as the \textsc{3sg} agent in ergative alignment) here in fact is referring to the plural entity muṣṭookhurá `forelegs'.
Content 1: \gll muṣṭookhur-á dhraǰaá ba \textbf{tíi} \textbf{ǰhulí} ṣiṣ čhoor-í ba bhéṭ-u | \gls foreleg-PL stretch.out.CV TOP 3SG.OBL on head put-CV TOP sit.down.PFV"=MSG | \glt `Stretching out its forelegs, it put its head on them/there and sat down.'

Knowledge Point: Used with abstract nouns it can encode a~whole range of meanings, some of them probably shading out into idiomatic expressions. The more common ones denote the topic of an~utterance `on, about, concerning', a~reason for something to happen `due to, with that', as in (\ref{ex:7-61}), or the means or attitude by which something is carried out.
Content 1: \gll lhooméi \textbf{teeṇíi} \textbf{mákar-a} \textbf{ǰhulí} askúun-a baándi kuhée díi nikhéet-i | \gls fox REFL cunning-OBL on ease-OBL on well.OBL from appear.PFV-F | \glt `The fox easily got out of the well due to his own cunning.'

Knowledge Point: The reason reading is also the usual when ǰhulí takes a~Verbal Noun as its argument (\sectref{subsec:13-4-3}). In this abstract usage, another postpostion, baándi, also in (\ref{ex:7-61}), a~loan from Pashto, is alternatively used, particularly in A. Some arguments with ǰhulí are part of the valence pattern of some predicates, particularly non"=nominative experiencers and objects of some conjunct verbs (\sectref{subsec:12-2-6} and \sectref{subsec:12-2-8} respectively).
Content 1: \gll lhooméi \textbf{teeṇíi} \textbf{mákar-a} \textbf{ǰhulí} askúun-a baándi kuhée díi nikhéet-i | \gls fox REFL cunning-OBL on ease-OBL on well.OBL from appear.PFV-F | \glt `The fox easily got out of the well due to his own cunning.'

Knowledge Point: \spitzmarke{maǰí `among, in, inside, during'.} This postposition takes an~oblique nominal argument in its spatial (and temporal) sense `in, into, inside', an~animate oblique plural nominal or accusative plural argument in the sense `among, out of', whereas the oblique form is used when its temporal sense is expressed with a~pronoun. One of the basic uses of maǰí is to single somebody out as part of a~group, as in example (\ref{ex:7-62}), `of them' or `among them'. The argument taken is always a~plural entity or a~collective expression.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{tanaám} \textbf{maǰí} áak míiš muṭ-á ǰe ukh-áai bhóo de | \gls 3PL.ACC among one man tree-OBL up ascend-INF be.able.3SG PST | \glt `Of them only one man was able to climb the tree.'

Knowledge Point: The other basic use of this postposition is to express a~position inside of something, the `bazaar' in (\ref{ex:7-63}), often in a~certain geographical location.
Content 1: \gll a ɣaríb méeš \textbf{baazúur-a} \textbf{maǰí} teeṇíi kuṇaák bhanǰ-úu de | \gls IDEF poor man bazaar-OBL in REFL child beat-3SG PST | \glt `A poor man was beating his own child in [the middle of] the bazaar.'

Knowledge Point: It is also used for the movement of something `into' another something, as in (\ref{ex:7-63b}).
Content 1: \gll ak muṭ-á wée \textbf{trúu} \textbf{šúunɡ-am} \textbf{maǰí} so mhaás čhúuṇ-u | \gls IDEF tree-OBL in three branch-PL.OBL in.between DEF.MSG.NOM meat put.down.PFV-MSG | \glt `He placed it between three branches in a tree.'

Knowledge Point: As mentioned above, maǰí can also be used in a~temporal sense, `while, at, during', with an~oblique pronoun such as in (\ref{ex:7-64}), a~nominal time expression or a~Verbal Noun (\sectref{subsec:13-4-1}).
Content 1: \gll \textbf{tíi} \textbf{maǰí} áa ǰhaṭíl-u ṭhaaṭáaku yhóol-u | \gls 3SG.OBL at IDEF hairy-MSG monster come.PFV"=MSG | \glt `Meanwhile a~hairy monster came in.'

Knowledge Point: \spitzmarke{túuri `under, beneath, below'.} This postposition takes an~oblique nominal argument, e.g., the `deodar tree' in (\ref{ex:7-65}), or an~accusative (alternatively oblique) pronominal argument. It describes a~position which is in a~purely spatial sense the opposite to that of ǰhulí, but it is not particularly frequent in my data. It typically expresses the position in or the movement into a~position lower than or beneath something. It can also be used with abstract nouns such as `agreement' in (\ref{ex:7-65b}).
Content 1: \gll karáaṛu \textbf{se} \textbf{loomuṭ-á} \textbf{túuri} yeí ba | \gls leopard DEF deodar.tree-OBL under come.CV TOP | \glt `The leopard got in under the deodar tree.'

Knowledge Point: Either an~oblique or an~accusative pronoun can be taken as an~argument of this postposition referring to an~inanimate entity, the former exemplified in (\ref{ex:7-66}), and the latter in (\ref{ex:7-67}). Whether this reflects a~dialectal difference or is just an~example of free variation, is a~matter for further study.
Content 1: \gll karáaṛu \textbf{tíi} \textbf{túuri} bheš-í=n-u | \gls leopard 3SG.OBL under sit.down-CV=be.PRS"=MSG | \glt `The leopard was sitting under it [the tree].'
Content 2: \gll dharíit-u tasíi so wíi tas ba anɡóor-a ǰhulí čhoor-í ba khaṭúur-a d-áan-a \textbf{tas} \textbf{túuri} | \gls remain.PFV"=MSG 3SG.GEN DEM.MSG.NOM water 3SG.ACC TOP fire-OBL on put-CV TOP log-PL give-PRS"=MPL 3SG.ACC under | \glt `The remaining water is then heated by building a fire under it with large pieces of wood.'

Knowledge Point: \spitzmarke{wée `in, on, into'.} This spatial postposition takes an~oblique nominal argument or an~oblique pronominal argument. It is exclusively used as a~postposition of nouns or pronouns with inanimate referents. In most cases it signals contact with the surface of something, as the fruit put into the bag in (\ref{ex:7-68}), or the penetration into a~location or beneath the surface of an~object, such as the hunter sitting in the tree in (\ref{ex:7-69}), i.e., inside the structure of tree branches. This latter characterisation is basically what differentiates it from the locative use of the oblique case of a~noun or a~locative pro"=adverb as well as the use of the goal"=specific postposition the with a~noun. It seems, however, that many locative nominal expressions can occur almost interchangeably as oblique nouns and as nouns followed by wée. Perhaps the postposition serves a~function of further emphasising the locative reading, especially when a~movement is implied.
Content 1: \gll tíi so meewá samaṭ-í ba \textbf{booǰée} \textbf{wée} de wheelíl-u | \gls 3SG.OBL DEF.MSG.NOM fruit collect-CV TOP bag.OBL in put.CV take.down.PFV"=MSG | \glt `He collected the fruit, put it into the bag and brought it down [home].'
Content 2: \gll so iškaarí méeš \textbf{muṭ-á} \textbf{wée} hín-u | \gls DEF.MSG.NOM hunter man tree-OBL in be.PRS"=MSG | \glt `The man is in the tree.'

Knowledge Point: The noun taking this postposition may also be an~abstract entity, such as `our school class' in (\ref{ex:7-70}).
Content 1: \gll \textbf{asíi} \textbf{ǰameet-í} \textbf{wée} áaṣṭ kuṇaak-á hín-a | \gls 1PL.GEN class-OBL in eight child-PL be.PRS"=MPL | \glt `There are eight children in our class.'

Knowledge Point: \spitzmarke{ǰe `up (into), up (along)'.} This rather specialised spatial postposition takes an oblique nominal argument or an~oblique pronominal argument. It is exclusively used with nouns or pronouns with inanimate referents. It is similar to wée, in that it signals contact with the surface of something or the penetration into a~location, but it is restricted to an~upward movement, such as that of the hunter making his way up into the tree in (\ref{ex:7-71}), and it occurs mostly with verbs having a~connotation of upward movement. It seems that this postposition primarily has a~connotation of movement, but there are examples of it being used in a~static sense as well.
Content 1: \gll hasó iškaarí ba bhíilam-e \textbf{loomuṭ-á} \textbf{ǰe} huṇṭráak ukháat-u | \gls REM.MSG.NOM hunter TOP fear-GEN deodar.tree-OBL up upward come.up.PFV"=MSG | \glt `Due to fear, that hunter climbed into a~deodar tree.'

Knowledge Point: \spitzmarke{thíi `from'.} This spatial postposition takes a~genitive nominal argument, but there is no evidence for any pronominal forms occurring with it. It is exclusively used with inanimate nouns (and as a~directional specifier of spatial adverbs, see \sectref{subsec:7-1-2}) and is in many ways used interchangeably with a~locative nominal expression in the genitive case. However, it may serve a~function of emphasising the movement away from (as it does when used with certain adverbs), whether in a~concrete spatial sense, as in (\ref{ex:7-72}), or in an~extended temporal sense, as in (\ref{ex:7-73}), although the latter is not very common.
Content 1: \gll ée wíi tu xu \textbf{sóon"=ii} \textbf{thíi} wh-áand-u | \gls o water 2SG.NOM apparently pasture-GEN from come.down-PRS"=MSG | \glt `O water, I see you are coming down from the high pasture.'
Content 2: \gll rhoošnaám \textbf{waxt-íi} \textbf{thíi} be c̣híitr-a be kráam th-íia | \gls morning time-GEN from 1PL.NOM field-OBL go.CV work do-1PL | \glt `Let's go to the field early in the morning and work.'

Knowledge Point: \spitzmarke{khúna/kéeči `(near) to, with'.} These two synomymous postpositions take an oblique nominal argument (\ref{ex:7-75}) or an~accusative pronominal argument (\ref{ex:7-74}). They are almost exclusively postposed to nouns or pronouns with animate (and particularly human) referents. It can describe the position `near to, at, with' as well as the movement `(near) to'. In the directional meaning, khúna/kéeči may also be followed by the `to' in a~postpositional sequence (see \sectref{subsec:7-2-4}).
Content 1: \gll tusím \textbf{lúuɡ-a} \textbf{míiš-a} \textbf{kéeči} ma baasaá míi bheezatí thawéel-i | \gls 2PL.ERG strange-OBL man-OBL with 1SG.NOM spend.night.CV 1SG.GEN disgrace cause.to.do.PFV-F | \glt `You disgraced me by making me spend the night with a~stranger.'
Content 2: \gll amzarái \textbf{tas} \textbf{khúna} yhóol-u hín-u | \gls lion 3SG.ACC near.to come.PFV"=MSG be.PRS"=MSG | \glt `The lion approached him.'

Knowledge Point: \spitzmarke{šíiṭi `in, inside'.} This postposition also used as a~spatial adverb (see \sectref{subsec:7-1-2}) takes an~oblique nominal argument or an~oblique pronominal argument. It is exclusively postposed to nouns or pronouns with inanimate referents, particularly those denoting enclosed areas or places, such as the `house' in (\ref{ex:7-76}). It can describe the position `in, inside' as well as the movement `into, inside'.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{eení} \textbf{ɡhooṣṭ-á} \textbf{šíiṭi} ma seé hín-u | \gls PROX house-OBL inside 1SG.NOM sleep.CV be.PRS"=MSG | \glt `Inside this very house I was asleep.'

Knowledge Point: \spitzmarke{pharé (B phará) `along, through, across, over'.} This postposition takes an oblique nominal argument or an~oblique pronominal argument. It is exclusively used as a~postposition of nouns or pronouns with inanimate referents. It expresses an~outstretched contact of one entity with the surface of another entity or that the two are located parallel to one another. Typically this is the way of expressing path, as in (\ref{ex:7-77}).
Content 1: \gll hazrát iisa=aleehisalaám \textbf{eesé} \textbf{páand-a} \textbf{pharé} bi-áan-u | \gls Lord Isa=peace.be.upon.him REM path-OBL along go-PRS"=MSG | \glt `Lord Isa [Jesus], PBUH, came walking along that path.'

Knowledge Point: However, this postposition can capture a~number of slightly different, but still related, positions and movements, such as the bread put on the mouth of the dead man in example (\ref{ex:7-78}).
Content 1: \gll tas mheer-í ɡal-í zaalim"=aan-óom \textbf{dhút-a} \textbf{pharé} ɡúuli bi de ɡíia de | \gls 3SG.ACC kill-CV throw-CV brute-PL"=OBL mouth-OBL toward bread also put.CV go.PFV.PL PST | \glt `The brutes, who had killed him, had also put bread in his mouth and left.'

Knowledge Point: \spitzmarke{dúši/ḍáḍi `toward, at, in the direction of'.} This postposition takes an~oblique nominal argument or an~accusative pronominal argument if animate and an oblique argument if inanimate and locative. While dúši is used in A as well as in B, ḍáḍi seems to be most common in B. It is used with nouns or pronouns with human or animate referents as well as with locative expressions, such as the `village' in (\ref{ex:7-79}).
Content 1: \gll \textbf{díiš-a} \textbf{dúši} tilíl-i hín-i | \gls village-OBL toward walk.PFV-F be.PRS-F | \glt `She started to walk toward the village.'

Knowledge Point: \spitzmarke{maxadúši (B muxadúši) `before, in front of'.} This diachronically complex postposition (with the above introduced dúši as one of its components) is also used as an~adverb. It takes a~genitive argument, kuṇaak-íi in (\ref{ex:7-80}), which in most cases has a~human referent. The relation expressed is commonly of an~abstract kind. For temporal precedence a~compound postposition díi muṣṭú/díi muxáak `before' is used (\sectref{subsec:7-2-3}).
Content 1: \gll \textbf{kuṇaak-íi} \textbf{maxadúši} šóo kráam ta th"=eeṇḍeéu | \gls child-GEN in.front.of good.MSG work CNTR do-OBLG | \glt `One should act properly in front of children.'

Knowledge Point: \spitzmarke{patú `after, behind'.} This postposition takes an~oblique nominal argument, as in (\ref{ex:7-81}), or an~accusative pronominal argument. While the same word is almost exclusively used as a~subordinate conjunction in B (corresponding to pahúrta in A), it primarily expresses a~spatial relationship in A. It is also used in the sense of being `in the pursuit of' something.
Content 1: \gll pal-í \textbf{áak} \textbf{ṭómb-a} \textbf{patú} | \gls hide-CV IDEF trunk-OBL behind | \glt `I hid behind a~tree trunk and...'

Knowledge Point: \spitzmarke{tií `until, up to, as far as'.} This postposition takes an~oblique nominal (and inanimate) argument, `knees' in (\ref{ex:7-83}), or, if referring to a~point in time or space, a~locative spatial adverb, as seen with eeṛáa in (\ref{ex:7-82}). It shows that something extends to a~specific point in space or time.
Content 1: \gll heewand-á \textbf{khúṭ-am} \textbf{tií} kir d-áan-u | \gls winter-OBL knee-OBL.PL as.far.as snow give-PRS"=MSG | \glt `In the winter the snow reaches up to the knees.'
Content 2: \gll \textbf{eeṛáa} \textbf{tií} ta máa=the šiǰrá páta náin-u | \gls there.DIST up.to CNTR 1SG.NOM=to line knowledge NEG.be.PRS"=MSG | \glt `I don't know his line until that point.'

Knowledge Point: \spitzmarke{dapáara (A)/pándee (B) `for'.} This postposition, which expresses purpose (if inanimate) or beneficiary (if human), takes a~genitive argument. The beneficiary use can be seen in (\ref{ex:7-84}).
Content 1: \gll ma ba aní pooštrá abaíim \textbf{thíi} \textbf{dapáara} saat-áan-u=ee | \gls 1SG.NOM TOP PROX fattened she.goat.PL 2SG.GEN for keep-PRS"=MSG=Q | \glt `Do you think I have taken care of these fattened goats for you?'

Knowledge Point: When a~purpose is expressed pronominally, it is the form of the pro"=adverb that expresses a~movement from a~location (i.e., an~ablative) that is being used, e.g., eeṛáai (\ref{ex:7-85}) in A, or hatáawuu (\ref{ex:7-86}) in B. The postposition dapáara/pándee may also take as an~argument a~Verbal Noun in a~purpose clause, (see \sectref{subsec:13-4-2}).
Content 1: \gll \textbf{eeṛáai} \textbf{dapáara} muxtalíf muxtalíf teeṇ-teeṇíi saamaán hín-i | \gls from.there.DIST for different different RED"=REFL things be.PRS-F | \glt `For that a~lot of different things are needed.'
Content 2: \gll súun-a the \textbf{hatáawuu} \textbf{pándee} har-áan-a | \gls pasture-OBL to from.there for take.away-PRS"=MPL | \glt `That is why we take them to the high pasture.'

Knowledge Point: The spatial adverb nhiáaṛa `near, nearby' (see \sectref{subsec:7-1-2}) occurs with the postposition the `to', meaning `near to, close to', as in example (\ref{ex:7-87}).
Content 1: \gll malikc̣heétr thaní \textbf{ɡhróom-a} \textbf{the} \textbf{nhiáaṛa} áak c̣híitr hín-u | \gls Malikchetre QUOT village-OBL to near IDEF field be.PRS"=MSG | \glt `Near to the village, there is a~field called Malikchetre.'

Knowledge Point: The adverb component in the compound can be further modified, such modifications, in (\ref{ex:7-88}) tuúš bi, occurring between the adverb and the simple postposition.
Content 1: \gll se \textbf{wíi-a} \textbf{the} \textbf{tuúš} \textbf{bi} \textbf{nhiáaṛa} ɡíi hín-i | \gls DEF water-OBL to a.little also near go.PFV.F be.PRS-F | \glt `She went a~bit closer to the water.'

Knowledge Point: If the argument is human, e.g., `me' in (\ref{ex:7-89}), a~compound keeči the nhiáaṛa, consisting of a~postpositional sequence (\sectref{subsec:7-2-4}) and an~adverb, is used.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{ma} \textbf{kéeči} \textbf{the} \textbf{nhiáaṛa} bheš | \gls 1SG.NOM with to near sit.down.IMP.SG | \glt `Sit down next to me!'

Knowledge Point: The temporal adverb muṣṭú (B muxáak) `before, in the past' (see \sectref{subsec:7-1-3}) occurs with the postposition díi `from', meaning `prior to', as in example (\ref{ex:7-91}). The compound díi muṣṭú/muxáak also occurs with Verbal Nouns in temporal subordination (\sectref{subsec:13-4-1}).
Content 1: \gll asíi dóodu c̣hoók \textbf{kaṭur-á} \textbf{díi} \textbf{dúu} \textbf{sóo} \textbf{kaal-á} \textbf{muṣṭú} yhóol-u hín-u | \gls 1PL.GEN grandfather Choke Kator-OBL from two hundred year-PL before come.PFV"=MSG be.PRS"=MSG | \glt `Our ancestor Choke arrived two hundred years prior to the Kator [dynasty].'

Knowledge Point: \spitzmarke{díi dhuúra `far from, away from'.} The spatial adverb muṣṭú (B dhuúra) `far away' (see \sectref{subsec:7-1-2}) occurs with the postposition díi `from', meaning `far from, away from', as in example (\ref{ex:7-92}).
Content 1: \gll taníi c̣híitr ba \textbf{taníi} \textbf{ɡhooṣṭ-á} \textbf{díi} \textbf{taqriibán} \textbf{tróo} \textbf{čúur} \textbf{kulumiṭer-á} \textbf{dhúura} de | \gls 3PL.GEN field TOP 3PL.GEN house-OBL from about three four kilometre-PL away.from be.PST | \glt `Their field was about three to four kilometres away from their house.'

Knowledge Point: Another kind of complex postposition consists of a~sequence of two simple postpositions. The first in the sequence is the semantically more central one, whereas the second is a~further fine"=tuning or specification, usually as far as the direction is concerned. Exactly which postpositions can and which cannot be combined in this fashion is a~matter of further research; (\ref{ex:7-93})--(\ref{ex:7-98}) are only a~few illustrative examples. It should be noted that the noun preceding the postpositional sequence is regularly assigned case by the first component of the sequence. The (nominally derived) postposition dúši, itself assigning oblique case to the preceding noun in (\ref{ex:7-96}), receives genitive marking from the second postposiion thíi.
Content 1: \gll \textbf{ḍúkur-a} \textbf{šíiṭi} \textbf{the} ɡhin-í ɡíia hín-a | \gls hut-OBL inside to take-CV go.PFV.PL be.PRS"=MPL | \glt `They brought him inside the hut.'
Content 2: \gll \label{bkm:Ref193771773}\textbf{ǰeep-í} \textbf{wée} \textbf{yúu} se ɡhambúri-m ɡhaḍíl-im | \gls pocket-OBL in from DEF flower-PL take.out.PFV"=FPL | \glt `He brought out the flowers from inside his pocket.'
Content 3: \gll aakatí kasaán nikháat-a \textbf{ɡiḍ-á} \textbf{dúšii} \textbf{\textmd{thíi}} | \gls some persons appear.PFV"=MPL Damel-OBL toward.GEN from | \glt `A few people came down, from the Damel side.'

Knowledge Point: The second component in the sequence wée yúu in (\ref{ex:7-98}) does not occur as an~independent postposition but is certainly related to the ablative function of this particular segment (y)uu/w(uu) occurring in a~few spatial expressions, especially in the B variety: hatáa-(w)uu `from there', aṛáa-(y)uu `from there', índee-(y)uu `from here', ɡóo-(y)uu `from where', but also as -oo in some temporal adverbs in A (see \sectref{subsec:7-1-3} above). \citeauthor{schmidtkohistani2001} mention a~rare ablative suffix -nyuu/nuu/uu in Kohistani Shina with a~very similar distribution (\citeyear[130]{schmidtkohistani2001}).
Content 1: \gll \label{bkm:Ref193771773}\textbf{ǰeep-í} \textbf{wée} \textbf{yúu} se ɡhambúri-m ɡhaḍíl-im | \gls pocket-OBL in from DEF flower-PL take.out.PFV"=FPL | \glt `He brought out the flowers from inside his pocket.'
